## Python Codeblock {collapse="true"}
@fig-cost below illustrates a line plot on a polar axis.

Do this once at the top of your notebook/script:
```{python}
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.rcParams.update({
    "font.family": "serif",
    "font.serif": ["STIX Two Text"],
    "mathtext.fontset": "stix",   # makes math match the font
    "savefig.format": "svg",  # default save format
    "savefig.transparent": True, # true transparent background for matplotlib figures
    "figure.facecolor": "none",
    "axes.facecolor": "none",
})

#In Jupyter / Quarto notebooks: make display SVGs by default
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = "svg" 
```

Below is the code to generate a figure.

```{python}
#| label: fig-cost  
#| fig-cap: "A line plot on cost per stage."

# toy example: cost-per-stage as a convex function of a 1D state
states = np.arange(0, 21)
cost = (states - 10) ** 2 / 10.0  # centered quadratic cost

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 3.5))
ax.plot(states, cost, marker="o", lw=2, label="cost-per-stage $c(x)$")
ax.set_xlabel("state $x$")
ax.set_ylabel("cost $c(x)$")
ax.set_title("Toy cost-per-stage over states")
ax.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.grid()
plt.show()


print("States:", states)
print("Cost-per-stage:", cost)
```

Below is another code to generate @fig-cost-2.

```{python}
#| label: fig-cost-2  
#| fig-cap: "Another line plot on cost per stage."  
#| collapse: true                 
#| echo: false  # suppress code display
# Create another plot similar to the first example
states = np.arange(0, 21)
cost = np.sin(states - 10) ** 2 / 10.0

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 3.5))
ax.plot(states, cost, marker="s", lw=2, label="cost-per-stage c(x)", color="orange")
ax.set_xlabel("state (x)")
ax.set_ylabel("cost c(x)")
ax.set_title("Another toy cost-per-stage over states")
ax.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.grid()
plt.show()
```

### Examples of Callout Blocks

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Assumption 2.2.2: 
We assume that $\mathbb{K}$ contains the graph of a measurable function from $X \to A$; that is there is a measurable function $f: X \to A$ such that $f(x) \in A(x), \forall x \in X$. The family of such function is denoted by $\mathbb{F}$ (see Definition 2.3.1). 
:::

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## Definition 2.2.1: Markov control model
A Markov control model is a five-tuple
$$
(X, A, \{A(x)|x\in X\}, Q, c)
$$
consisting of

a) a Borel space $X$, called the state space and whose elements are refered to as states;
a) a Borel space $A$, called the control or action set;
a) a family $\{A(x) | x\in X\}$ of nonempty measurable subsets $A(x)$ of $A$, where $A(x)$ denote the set of feasible controls or actions when the system is in state $x$, with the property that the set 
$$
\mathbb{K} := \{(x, a)|x\in X, a\in A(x)\}
$$
of feasible state-actions pairs is a measurable subset of $X\times A$;
a) a stochastic kernel $Q$ on $X$ given $\mathbb{K}$ called transition law;
a) a measurable function $c: \mathbb{K} \to \mathbb{R}$ called cost-per-stage (or one-stage cost) function.
:::
